nodes.text: Land price can contain a rational bubble even when the observed housing rent-to-price ratio is non-vanishing; distinguishing pure land rent from housing-structure rent is necessary to detect such bubbles

Some empirical skeptics dismiss rational land or housing bubbles because they observe stationarity in the aggregate rent-to-price (price-rent) ratio and argue a bubble would imply vanishing rent yield
It is essential to separate rent accruing to the housing structure from pure land rent because aggregate housing rent may be dominated by structure rent while land rent dynamics can differ

We analyze a two-period overlapping generations model with consumption good and housing service, Cobb-Douglas utility with parameters beta_y, beta_o, beta_h, unit supply of non-reproducible land, and a representative firm producing housing from construction material and land
Assume housing production function F(M,X) is homogeneous of degree one, C1 with positive marginal products, concave, and satisfies lim_{M->0} (F_X/F_M)(M,1)=0 (Inada-type condition)
In equilibrium with the model and Cobb-Douglas preferences, aggregate rent-to-price ratio r_t h_t / P_t is constant and equals beta_h / beta_o (Proposition 1)

There exists a unique equilibrium characterized by the expenditure shares and conditions (equations 7-10); the equilibrium variables M_t, h_t, D_t, P_t are pinned down by these conditions (Proposition 2)
Characterization: a land bubble exists if and only if the sum over t of FX/F(M_t,1) is finite, where M_t solves the equilibrium condition (equation 14)
Derivation: the land dividend yield D_t/P_t equals (beta_h / beta_o) times FX/F(M_t,1), linking production elasticities to dividend yield in equilibrium
Apply the Bubble Characterization Lemma: an asset exhibits a bubble iff the infinite sum of dividend yields D_t/P_t is finite, which connects the FX/F condition to the presence of a bubble
For a CES production function with elasticity of substitution sigma>1, FM/F ~ M^{-1} and FX/F ~ const * M^{1/sigma -1} as M->infinity (asymptotics, equation 15)

Proposition 3: with CES production (sigma>1) there is a land bubble iff the sum over t of e_t^{1/sigma -1} is finite; under sustained economic growth e_t ~ G^t with G>1 this condition holds and land bubbles inevitably emerge

Although aggregate housing rent-to-price ratio can be constant (non-vanishing), the pure land dividend yield can vanish fast enough to satisfy the bubble criterion, so observing a non-vanishing aggregate rent yield does not rule out land bubbles

Model simplifications include: housing fully depreciates each period and agents consume housing only when transitioning from young to old; these assumptions reduce dimensionality but may limit realism
Implication: empirical studies must separate pure land rent from housing-structure rent to assess the existence of land bubbles; failure to separate them can lead to incorrect dismissal of bubbles
